metadata.case_name: Nathoo Lal v. Son of Mst. Bhuri

facts.text: Property originally belonged to Ramchandra who died sonless in 1903, survived by mother Sheokori, widow Mst. Badni, and daughters Bhuri and Laxmi.
Ramchandra made an oral will bequeathing the property to daughter Laxmi.
On 6th September 1906, Mst. Sheokori and Mst. Badni executed and registered a deed of gift of the property to Mst. Laxmi purporting to act per oral will.
Gift deed recitals: Houses gifted according to will of father Ramchandra; he directed registration in Laxmi's name; no other claim; Laxmi to deal as she likes.
Mst. Laxmi died in 1928, remained in possession till death.
On 5th July 1930, Balabux (Laxmi's husband) mortgaged house to defendant appellant Nathoo Lal.
On 5th October 1933, Balabux sold house to Nathoo Lal and put him in possession; Nathoo Lal in possession since.

Plaintiff (son of Mst. Bhuri) filed suit on 4th October 1945 (one day before 12 years from defendant's entry) for possession, claiming possession till 24th August 1933 via tenant, then locked and went to village; learnt of dispossession on 27th September 1944.
Plaintiff alleged Balabux had no right to mortgage/sell; Laxmi had only limited estate.
Plaintiff admitted Ramchandra made will in favour of Laxmi; grandmothers executed gift deed per will; Laxmi possessed till death; kept plaintiff as son, rents in his name.
Trial court (Civil Judge, Jaipur City) dismissed suit on 23rd August 1947: Laxmi absolute owner, plaintiff no title, suit within limitation.
District Judge affirmed on 15th April 1948: widow executed per oral will, Laxmi absolute estate, plaintiff in possession within 12 years.

Jaipur High Court in second appeal allowed plaintiff's appeal: plaintiff in possession till dispossessed 5th Oct 1933 even during Laxmi's life; oral will conferred only limited life estate on Laxmi, reverts to heirs; decreed suit with costs.
Review application heard by Rajasthan High Court (successor), partially allowed 5th April 1950: plaintiff entitled to possession on payment of Rs. 4000 for improvements/repairs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was barred by limitation.
Whether oral will of Ramchandra conferred absolute interest on Laxmi or only limited life estate.
Maintainability of appeal to Supreme Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit barred by limitation as plaintiff failed to prove possession after 24th August 1933; no evidence of locking house.
Laxmi acquired absolute title under father's oral will; no need for express words for absolute interest to female heir.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Law; no presumption of limited estate

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal not maintainable as Jaipur High Court decision final under local CPC; review only on improvements, not reopening merits.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Jaipur State Code of Civil Procedure

respondent_arguments.text: No certificate should have been granted.
Ramchandra intended gift but could not register; widows inherited limited estate, gifted only that to Laxmi.
No evidence of oral will terms conferring absolute interest; presumption of limited life estate to female heir.

court_reasoning.text: Appeal maintainable as operative decree is Rajasthan HC 1950 post-Constitution; Article 133 applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jaipur CPC irrelevant to SC jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate properly granted: substantial question of law on estate to female under Hindu will; property value >20,000.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Would admit under Art 136 if not.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff's possession continued post-Laxmi's death till dispossessed; presumption of continuity even without locking.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Three lower courts unanimous; suit within limitation.

court_reasoning.text: Oral will to Laxmi admitted; gift deed executed per will; recitals show absolute ownership intent; Laxmi sole beneficiary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Testator intended to confer same title he had.

court_reasoning.text: No presumption of limited estate to Hindu female; words of full ownership suffice without express alienation power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overrules old Privy Council interpretation; per recent SC in Ram Gopal.

holdings.text: Operative decree of 5th April 1950 appealable under Article 133.
Suit within limitation; possession presumed continuous.
Oral will conferred absolute estate on Laxmi; she absolute owner; devolves to husband Balabux with full alienation rights; plaintiff no heir.
No presumption that Hindu will/gift to female confers only limited estate absent express words; general Hindu law principle of inheritance applies.

precedents_cited.relevance: Old PC case holding bequest to daughter-in-law passes limited estate; later clarified no presumption.
No presumption for/against absolute estate to female; same as male.
Settles no warrant for presumption of limited estate to Hindu female; words of ownership suffice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mst. Kollani Kuar v. Luchmi Kuar
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasoning approved by PC; general principle if estate to man without inheritance words, carries inheritance.
Estate to man without express inheritance carries inheritance by Hindu Law.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Embodies general principle of inheritance in grants.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decree of Rajasthan High Court set aside; trial court decree dismissing plaintiff's suit restored.
outcome.relief_granted: None to plaintiff; possession remains with appellant Nathoo Lal.

key_quotes.text: "These houses are made a gift to you according to the will of your father, Ramchandra... You deal with your house in any way you like."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Gift deed recitals showing absolute ownership intent.

key_quotes.text: "Ramchandra had made a will in favour of Mst. Laxmi... Through this gift deed Mst. Laxmi held possession over it till she was alive."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: "It may be taken to be quite settled that there is no warrant for the proposition of law that when a grant of an immovable property is made to a Hindu female, she does not get an absolute or alienable interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding from Ram Gopal; no presumption of limited estate.
